system: You are a resident physician tasked with writing a discharge summary letter of a patient from the patient's Electronic Health Records.
user:
The letter is written to a patient when leaving hospital after a stay for the review. It should be prose and not contain bullet points.
Include summary of stay including, if applicable, key issues, interventions, procedures, and treatments.
Include summary of condition at discharge.
Include recommendations for follow-up plans and ongoing treatment.
Write the text in the style of a discharge letter using medical terminology. Proceed chronologically, write factually, objectively and concretely, formally, professionally, politely, respectfully. Avoid generalizations, assumptions, verbose and cumbersome formulations, and redundancy. Do not invent or presume anything. Generally, formulate in the imperfect tense, reported speech from individuals (e.g., from patients) in subjunctive I, and medical assessments and diagnoses in the present tense.
Minimize hallucinations. Do not generate recommendations on your own or add anything. Write nothing about topics for which there is no information basis from the EHR.
Don't include all private information, such as ID and date of birth. Use ___ to represent names of patients and medical professionals.

This is an example of discharge summary letter:
Dear ___,

You came into hospital because you were getting more short of breath and your ankles were swollen.

A heart scan, called an echocardiogram, showed that your heart was not pumping as well as it should.

We started you on water tablets called Furosemide. They will stop fluid collecting in your legs and lungs.

Please take 2 Furosemide tablets (2 x 40 mg = 80 mg) each morning and weigh yourself each morning.

If your weight drops by more than 2 kg over the week, reduce the dose to 1 tablet per day.

We have asked your GP practice to see you in about 2 weeks' time. They will take a blood test to check your kidney function.

We will see you in 6 weeks' time in the Cardiology Outpatient Clinic.

You will receive an appointment letter in the post.

Sincerely,
____

Dear ___,

You were admitted to the hospital on March 10, 2024, following the onset of chest pain and shortness of breath, as reported by ambulance personnel. The initial evaluation included an electrocardiogram (ECG), which revealed significant ST elevation in leads v5-6. This finding suggested the presence of an acute ST-Elevation Myocardial Infarction (STEMI), specifically involving the left main coronary artery, diagnosed on March 11, 2024.

Upon your admission, you received standard management for myocardial infarction, adhering to the MONAC protocol, which included Morphine for pain relief and Nitroglycerin, administered at 0.4 mg every five minutes for up to three doses, to alleviate persistent chest pain. Aspirin, at a dose of 324 mg, was given as a single dose to help reduce clot formation. Supplemental oxygen was administered at 2-4 liters per minute as needed to maintain adequate oxygen saturation levels above 90%.

Laboratory investigations on March 11, 2024, revealed elevated levels of Troponin T, with results of 30 and 29, further confirming myocardial infarction. Despite attempts to proceed with percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) as per local guidelines, challenges were encountered in coordinating with the catheterization laboratory and on-call cardiology team, which resulted in the persistence of ST elevation on subsequent ECGs through the night.

On March 12, 2024, you expressed a desire to be discharged from the hospital, reporting that your chest pain had resolved. At discharge, your condition appeared stable, with no further episodes of chest discomfort.

It is paramount that you follow up with your primary care provider or a cardiologist for ongoing management of your cardiac condition. Please continue to monitor your symptoms, and if you experience any recurrence of chest pain, shortness of breath, or any other concerning symptoms, seek immediate medical attention.

For further engagement with your cardiology care, you will receive an appointment in the outpatient clinic to ensure appropriate follow-up and management of your condition.

We appreciate your cooperation during your stay and wish you a smooth recovery.

Sincerely,  
___
